question: Ðæt (wite) #### wæs strang⁠ — The punishment was strong
explanation: Here 'wite' is the subject and so takes no ending

question: Ða halgan (sawol) #### sint undeaþlice and ece⁠ — The holy souls are undying and eternal
explanation: Here 'sawol' is the subject and plural, so it loses its unstressed 'o' takes an 'a' ending

question: Nilt ðu habban yfelan (scoh) ####⁠ — You do not want to have an evil shoe
explanation: Here 'scoh' is masculine, the direct object and single, so it takes no ending

question: Hie heora (heafod) #### slogan on ða wagas⁠ — They struck their heads against the walls
explanation: Here 'heafod' is neuter, the direct object and plural so it loses its unstressed 'o' and gains a u

question: Ðæs (fugol) #### flyht wæs dyrne and degol⁠ — The bird's flight was hidden and secret
explanation: 'Fugol' is masculine and here it is possessive and single so it loses its unstressed 'o' and gains an 'es' ending

question: Ðara (wealh) #### cyning slog monige menn⁠ — The King of the foreigners slew many men
explanation: 'Wealh' is masculine and here it is the posessive plural, so it loses its 'h' and gains an 'a' ending

question: Sume wæron mid iserne (clawu) #### totorene⁠ — Some were torn with an icy claw
explanation: 'Clawu' is feminine and here it is a singular, indirect object so it loses its final vowel, 'u', and gains an 'e' ending

question: God ricsaþ on feower (ende) #### ðyses middangeardes⁠ — God rules in the four corners of the earth
explanation: Here 'ende' is an indirect object and plural, so it loses its final vowel, 'e', and gains a 'um' ending

question: Godes (engel) #### stod on emn him⁠ — God's angel stood before him
explanation: Here 'engel' is the subject and so takes no ending

question: He bletsode ða adrife (fæt) #### ond ða beagas⁠ — He blessed the engraved cups and the rings
explanation: 'Fæt' is neuter and here it is the direct object and plural, so its 'æ' changes to 'a' and it gains the 'u' ending

question: He waes on ðæs (hwæl) #### innoþe⁠ — He was in the whale's innards
explanation: Here 'hwæl' is in the possessive singular and so gains the 'es' ending

question: Her sindon nigon (engel) #### werod⁠ — Here are nine hosts of angels
explanation: Here 'engel' is in the posessive plural and so loses its unstressed 'e' and gains an 'a' ending

question: Hie coman on ðrim ceolum hider to Brytene on ðam (stede) #### Heopwines fleot⁠ — He came on three ships to Britain to the place called Heopwines fleet
explanation: Here 'stede' is an indirect object and singular, so it takes an 'e' ending. Since it already ends in 'e', and since end-vowels are dropped before a suffix, this makes it look like the word does not change

question: He wealdeþ sidum (rice) ####⁠ — He rules broad kingdoms
explanation: Here 'rice' is in the posessive plural and so loses its end-vowel and gains the 'um' ending

question: Seo (sceadu) #### byþ to underne seofon and twentigoþan healfes fotes⁠ — The shadow is twenty-seven and a half feet at 9am
explanation: Here 'sceadu' is the subject and singular and so takes no ending

question: Ðu eart eallra þinga fruma and (ende) ####⁠ — You are the beginning and end of all things
explanation: Here 'ende' is the direct object and singular and so takes no ending

question: We habbaþ eowre (scoh) #### on eowrum fotum⁠ — We have our shoes on our feet
explanation: 'Scoh' is masculine and here it is the direct object and plural so it should take an 'as' ending. Since it ends in 'h', it loses the 'h' and the unstressed vowel of the suffix when declined

question: Seo ydelnes is ðære (sawol) #### feond⁠ — Idleness is the soul's enemy
explanation: Here 'sawol' is in the posessive signular, so it loses its unstressed 'o' and gains the 'e' ending

question: 671 Her wæs ðæt micle (fugol) #### wæl⁠ — 671AD: here was the great slaughter of birds
explanation: Here 'fugol' is in the possessive plural, so it loses its unstressed 'o' and gains the 'a' ending

question: We sceolon fyligan urum (heafod) ####⁠ — We should follow our heads
explanation: Here 'heafod' is an indirect object and singular, so it loses its unstressed 'o' and gains the 'e' ending

commonMistakes.explanation: Here 'heafod' is an indirect object, not direct object, as the heads are not being directly acted upon. This means it takes the dative singular 'e' ending

question: Heo wæs to manegum (wite) #### geworht⁠ — She was put to many tortures
explanation: Here 'wite' is an indirect object and plural, so it loses its end-vowel and takes the 'um' ending

question: Hira (clawu) #### todælede beoþ⁠ — Their hooves are divided
explanation: Here 'clawu' is the subject and plural so it loses its end-vowel and gains the 'a' ending

commonMistakes.explanation: 'Clawu', like most words ending in 'u', is feminine, not masculine, so it takes the nominative plural 'a' ending

question: He gewanode his (feoh) #### and geihte his rihtwisnysse⁠ — He dimished his wealth and increased his righteousness
explanation: 'Feoh' is neuter and here it is the direct object and singular, so takes no ending

question: Wilt ðu fon (hwæl) ####?⁠ — Will you hunt whales?
explanation: Here 'hwæl' is the direct object and plural so its 'æ' changes to 'a' and it gains the 'as' ending

question: Ic þe þa faehðe leanige (feoh) #### ond ealdgestreonum, swa ic aer dyde⁠ — For the feud, I would reward you with wealth and old treasures, as I did before
explanation: Here 'feoh' is the indect object and singular so it loses its 'h'. It should take an 'e' ending but since it is an unstressed vowel, it takes no ending

commonMistakes.explanation: Here 'feoh' is the indect object and singular so it should take an 'e' ending, but since you drop the unstressed vowel along with the 'h', it takes no ending

question: Ða hie sæton þara ond innan Ionan tu winter on þam twam (stede) ####⁠ — Then settled there and on the Yonne, two winters in those two places
explanation: Here 'stede' is an indirect object and plural and so it drops its end-vowel and takes the 'um' ending

question: Se (stede) #### is halig ðe ðu on stenst⁠ — The place where you stand is holy
explanation: Here 'stede' is the subject and singular, so it takes no ending

question: (engel) #### God worhte, ða sind gastas, and nabbaþ nænne lichaman ⁠ — God created angels, which are spirits and have no body
explanation: 'Engel' is masculine and here it is the direct object, so it loses its unstressed 'e' and gains an 'as' ending

question: Eall Italia (rice) #### þæt betwux þam muntum ond Sicilia þam ealonde in anwald gerehton⁠ — All the kingdom of Italy that is between the mountains and the island of Sicily were subjugated
explanation: Here 'rice' is an indirect object and singular. Since it loses its end-vowel and gains an 'e', it looks like it does not gain an ending

question: Ic nu gange on midde þa (sceadu) #### deaðes, ne ondræde ic me nan yfel, forþam þu byst mid me⁠ — Though I walk through the valley of the shadow of death, I will fear no evil: for thou art with me
explanation: Here 'sceadu' is an indirect object and singular, so it loses its end-vowel and gains the 'e' ending
